channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: California, Oregon and Washington plan to join forces to preserve vaccine acce
item.description: The Democratic governors of three Western states — California, Oregon and Washington — say they will form a new public health partnership to preserve access to vaccines.

item.title: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. to testify in Senate hearing Thursday
item.description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. will testify in a Senate Finance Committee hearing Thursday, a week after turmoil and upheavals rocked the CDC.

item.title: Sen. Warren says banking panel should focus on Trump's attacks on Fed independence
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Sen. Elizabeth Warren, the top Democrat on the Senate Banking Committee, about Stephen Miran's nomination to the Fed and the central bank's independence.

item.title: A literary center named for author Larry McMurtry breathes life into his Texas hometown
item.description: A literary center in Archer City, a tiny ranching town in Texas, keeps alive the legacy of famed Western author Larry McMurtry.

item.title: NFL season kicks off Thursday night
item.description: NPR's A Martínez talks with Washington Post sports columnist Neil Greenberg about what to watch for as the NFL season kicks off.

item.title: What legal paths Trump has left in push to deploy more National Guard troops
item.description: NPR's Michel Martin speaks with Stephen Vladeck, professor of law at Georgetown University, about the Trump administration's remaining legal pathways for the deployment of National Guard troops.

item.title: Judge rules Trump administration illegally froze billions in Harvard funds
item.description: A federal judge found the Trump administration acted illegally when it froze more than $2.2 billion in research funding for Harvard University. The White House says it will appeal the decision.

item.title: 'Xena: Warrior Princess' turns 30
item.description: On Sept. 4, 1995, "Xena: Warrior Princess" premiered on syndicated TV. Lucy Lawless, the show's star, and Rob Tapert, her husband and "Xena" co-creator, talk about its popularity and legacy.

item.title: Secretary of State Marco Rubio says there could be more strikes on drug traffickers
item.description: U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio warns of more military strikes on drug traffickers, calling a U.S. strike on a Venezuelan boat a clear message to cartels.

item.title: Senate committee will hold confirmation hearing for Trump's latest Fed pick Thursday
item.description: A Senate committee will hold a confirmation hearing for President Trump's latest pick to serve on the Federal Reserve board. It comes as Trump tries to put his own stamp on the central bank.
